Addyston, Ohio
June 17, 1999
Rev. December 31, 2002

Executive summary for Risk Management Program  

1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Bayer Polymers LLC is committed to the principles of Responsible Care which emphasize operating in a safe and environmentally correct manner. Management systems are in place to assure all facilities are complying with these principles.  There are Corporate Engineering Standards and Health, Environment and Safety Guidelines which address every aspect of Risk Management from design of intrinsically safe processes and use of layers of protection to incident tracking and program audits. Bayer Polymers LLC a North American subsidiary of Bayer, AG, which is headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany.  Bayer Polymers LLC has its own corporate structure, policies and procedures which are consistent with those of the parent company, but are customized to meet US regulations and standards.  Bayer AG has established guidelines for Responsible Care in Environmental Protection and Safety, which includes a Directive for Process and Plant Safety that all Bayer facilities world-wide are expected to follow.  It provides guidance for safe process design and operation.

In the US, Bayer Polymers LLC is an active member of the American Chemistry Council?s Responsible Care Initiative.  Bayer has implemented all seven codes of management practice which have been verified in practice by a third party audit.  Bayer Polymers LLC has a Corporate Health, Environment and Safety Policy which states that it is the corporation?s responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and communities.  This is a primary responsibility, of equal importance to any other business objective.  This is supported in the corporation?s Vision, Values and Beliefs, which emphasize applying technical expertise to advance our business while assuring the safety and protection

of our employees, customers, communities and the environment.

The Bayer Polymers LLC Addyston facility has implemented all of the corporate Health Environment and Safety Policies and Guidelines through site policies and procedures.  These include site Safety and Health Procedures, Emergency Response Procedures, Process Safety Management Procedures, Hazard Communication Procedure and Risk Management Procedure as well as safety plans in the individual production unit Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).  The Bayer Polymers LLC Addyston facility is ISO 14001 certified. 

2.  FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The facility manufactures plastics and resins.  The plastic pellet products are sold to molders for end use in refrigerator and automobile interiors, medical uses, computer housings, health spas, tools, and much more. The resins are used to coat circuit boards and coat aluminum cans to allow printing on the can.

Two RMP chemicals are used in the facility, acrylonitrile and butadiene.  These make up two of the three main chemicals used to make the plastic products.  (The third being styrene, a non-RMP chemical).  Acrylonitrile is a liquid and stored in 2 tanks prior to being used in smaller tanks and in several plastic manufacturing processes.  Butadiene is stored under pressure in a tank.  All storage tanks have concrete dike floors and walls capable of holding more than the quantity of the material being stored.  Multiple processes use these chemicals in various quantities in a process at one time.   Acrylonitrile is the only toxic RMP chemical and represents the worst case scenario for toxic chemicals.  Butadiene is the only flammable RMP chemical and thus represents the worst case flammable scenario.

3A.  WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst case scenario for acrylonitrile assumes the following:
- Greatest quantity of acrylonitrile is release from the largest storage tank over a 10 minute period
- The release is into the concrete dike which

reduces the impact of the spill
- The release occurs during worst case weather conditions
- All safety precautions and emergency response at the facility fail

The worst case scenario for butadiene for west receptors assumes the following:
- Greatest quantity of butadiene is instantly released from 1 railroad car.
- The released vapors are ignited and explode.
- All safety and emergency response precautions at the facility fail.

The second worst case scenario for butadiene exists for a set of east receptors and assumes the following:
- Greatest quantity of butadiene is instantly released from the storage tank.
- The released vapors are ignited and explode.
- All safety and emergency response precautions at the facility fail.

3B.  ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The alternative case scenario for acrylonitrile assumes the following:
- Emergency vent release from a manufacturing process vessel:
- Typical weather conditions (as provided by EPA)

The alternative case scenario for butadiene assumes the following:
- A gasket in a pipeline fails and releases butadiene.   
- Sensors detect butadiene and operators respond immediately
- The released butadiene vapor is ignited
- Typical weather conditions (as provided by EPA)

4.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PRVENTION PROGRAM

This facility is an OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) the VPP STAR site, one of the highest Safety Awards given.  Under the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) OSHA has recognized this facility as having exceptional safety process, programs, and performance.  Here is a list of some of those safe practices:

ENGINEERING and DESIGN
- Detailed operating procedures
- Special equipment standards
- Special flanges, piping, valves
- Remotely operated isolation valves
- State of the art computerized controls, including alarm systems for early warning of problems
- Redundant & energy protected controls
- Control Room protection during emergencies
- Inventory minimized for hazardous materials
- Continuous

improvement of processes & equipment
- Hazard review for changes
- Color coding and labeling of piping & vessels
- Dikes and curbs to contain spills 
- Emergency tank to contain system upsets
- Spot ventilation system
- Continuous process analyzers
- Production units designed to withstand natural disasters
 
DETECTION
- Process and storage tank area monitoring for acrylonitrile and butadiene
- Control room air intake monitoring
- Portable monitors for leak detection
- Intense vessel inspection program (Internal and external)

TRAINING
- Refresher and safety training for all employees
- New employee qualification requirements
- Regular emergency response drills
- Specialized maintenance skills training
- Worker certification programs
- Off-site specialized training for emergency response teams    
                                                                                                                                                               INSPECTIONS and SAFETY REVIEWS
-Incident investigations and reviews
-Systematic equipment inspection
-Critical instrument and pressure relief valve inspections
- Process Hazard Analyses program
- Fugitive emissions monitoring program
- Safety audits of operating units
- Tracking system for recommendations
- Special permits required prior to maintenance work

MEDICAL MANAGEMENT
- Certified EMT?s 
- Physician on site 
- Physician?s nurse on site
 
MITIGATION
- Release containment equipment and materials at each unit
- Neutralization and decontamination procedures
- Fire water monitor guns near process and storage tanks 
- Foam vapor suppression capability

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
-Trained emergency spill response teams
- Written emergency action plans
- Fire brigade maintained on all shifts
- Fire brigade annual training and special training at Texas A&M Fire School
- Emergency alarm systems coded to expedite rapid emergency response
- Coordination with Addyston Emergency Operations Plan, LEPC, Hamilton County Emergency

Management Agency, and local Fire Departments
-Agreements with emergency response companies

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
-Periodic reviews of operating procedures
-Bayer employees make up 100% of emergency teams
-Employees participate on incident investigation teams
-Union employee safety trainers

The worst case scenarios are extremely unlikely events because of these extensive safety precautions in place at this facility.
                                                                                                                                                                            5.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been 3 accidents in the past five years that met the EPA definition of  ?accident? because they had the potential for any injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, environmental damage, or health impacts.  These are listed in the attached forms.  The installation of two containment systems and the shutdown of a process have significantly reduced the potential for an off site release from occurring. 

6.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

This facility has extensive emergency response capabilities and coordinates with outside agencies.  Here is a summary of these capabilities.
- All employees are trained for first level emergency response.
- We have trained fire brigade members on site 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
- We have fire trucks, including foam capability.
- We coordinate with local Fire Departments.
-A plant siren sounds for every plant alarm.  The alarm is coded to expedite response by the plant fore chief and emergency fire brigade.  The alarm is tested weekly.
-The Mayor and police department are notified on critical fire alarms along with other facilities (Hitchens Elementary and others) as needed.
- We conduct emergency drills.
- Public can be notified of chemical accidents through civil defense sirens, emergency weather radios, loud speakers on fire department vehicles or door-to-door notification via the Addyston Em

ergency Operations Plan.
- We coordinate with local communities for emergency communications. 
 
7.  PLANS TO IMPROVE SAFETY

This facility continues to improve the safety of this facility.  Here are the primary methods:
- Routine Process Hazards Audits are conducted on every operating unit in the plant.  Detailed audits recommendations are made to improve the safety of the process.
- New equipment is designed to the most modern safety standards and generally replaces older equipment.  
- Employees continue to provide specific safety suggestions to improve the safety of equipment, procedures, and processes.  
-The plant works with Addyston and surrounding response agencies to improve communications with emergency responders and the public should a chemical emergency occur.
